original_title: Sri Lanka Grama Niladhari unions express support for Janasbha system: secretariat
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Grama Nildhari unions have expressed their support for a proposed Janasabha or people’s council system, a statement said.

The Jathika Janasabha Secretariat or the National People’s Council Secretariat said in a statement on Tuesday August 08 that representatives of the All Ceylon Liberate Grama Niladari Association, Sri Lanka United Grama Niladari Association and Sri Lanka Grama Niladari Association shared their views on the system at a discussion held at the secretariat.

“The associations praised the development process that the Janasabha system could bring to rural areas. However, they also indicated their belief that the Janasabha Secretary selection process should be refined to ensure the proper candidates are chosen,” the statement said.
The meeting was attended by Chairman of the National Movement for a Just Society and former speaker Karu Jayasuriya and others.

In October 2022, Sri Lanka’s cabinet of ministers approved a proposal by President Ranil Wickemesinghe to adopt a people’s council system as “fundamental” government policy and also establish a National People’s Council Secretariat.

The secretariat was expected to serve as the national level independent central institution for establishing the proposed People’s Councils (Jana Sabha) system, aimed at strengthening participatory democracy in Sri Lanka.

Due to the gap between the center of governance and the people of the periphery, Sri Lanka’s representative democratic structures do not pay due attention to public opinion in the policy and decision-making process, a government information department statement said in October.

Opinions and objections against representative democracy are emerging in society, the statement claimed, highlighting the need for a “strong mechanism where public officials and the public can discuss rural issues together” and “determine development priorities”.

It will be possible to effectively and efficiently prevent public oppression that may occur due to bureaucracy and arbitrary politicisation through an organised mechanism that actively find public opinions for public policy formulation and implement those policies with community participation, the statement said.

The cabinet decision, according to the statement, was based on a concept paper by the National Movement for a Just Society on a People’s Council system with an independent institutional structure where public participation can be ensured for the formulation of public policies and the successful implementation of those policies.
The concept paper also proposed the establishment of the ‘National People’s Council’ and ‘Village People’s Councils’ to cover every Grama Niladhari division in the Island. (Colombo/Aug08/2023)
